title: British children trapped in Syria ‘could become terrorists if not brought home’
text:
Save the children counts at least 60 British children trapped in Syria (Picture: Getty Images)

At least 60 British children are believed to be trapped in north-east Syria after fleeing areas held by the Islamic State, Save the Children reports.

All the children have been born to British parents suspected of joining Isis, and many of them are under the age of five, numbers compiled by the UK charity show.

Three of them are orphans, while several of the older children are likely to have witnessed extreme brutality, beheadings and conflict.

Former Brexit secretary David Davis told the Commons that the children are at risk of ‘turning into terrorists’ if they are not brought home from Syria.

He argued that they should not be ‘punished for their parents’ mistakes’, adding that numerous other countries have used a ceasefire to repatriate children stranded in the country.

Many of them are under the age of five (Picture: Getty Images)

Mr Davis continued: ‘If we do not do the same, British children will be left at the whim of a brutal dictator or a terrorist organisation or roving bands of militia.

‘If we do nothing, we’ll be abandoning our moral obligations and risking those vulnerable children to growing up in a war-torn area and maybe turning into terrorists themselves.

Tiny baby born weighing less than one pound goes home after 150 days in hospital

‘The time to act, minister, is now.’

Foreign Office minister Andrew Murrison told Mr Davies he did not recognise the figure of 60 children but said Britain is already talking with agencies to do ‘all we can’.

He emphasised that the UK would be approaching the situation with ‘compassion and care’, but said the priority would be unaccompanied children and orphans.

Mr Murrison added that accessing the camps is ‘extremely difficult’, but outlined hope that the ceasefire in north-east Syria will be sustained, under which more opportunities would ‘become possible’.

The UK government has been urged to bring the children home (Picture: Getty Images)

Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry told the foreign minister that the government should also consider repatriating British mums in Syria to face justice in the UK.

She argued that there was a ‘moral and civic duty’ to give the British children the care they need – even if it also means bringing pack their mothers to go on trial.

Responding, Mr Murrison said: ‘These are innocent minors. They are vulnerable people and we must do what we can for them.

‘It is entirely wrong to associate them with what their parents may have done.’

Three British children were believed to have been evacuated from a detention camp at Ain Issa last week, Save the Children said.

Former Brexit secretary David Davis said the children are at risk of ‘turning into terrorists’ (Picture: Parliament.tv)

The charity’s head of humanitarian conflict and campaigns, Alison Griffin, stated that the vast majority of children were still with their mothers in Syria.

She said: ‘Children whose parents are alive are just as innocent as those who have been orphaned. All have been put through unimaginable horrors.

‘The foreign secretary has said he wants to ensure innocents are not caught in the crossfire.

‘To play his part to achieve that, he needs to act now while there’s still a window of opportunity and bring all the UK’s children home.”
